content.content: I’d like to clarify my position with regards to the capital raise in a succinct way, even if the topic has more nuances than the below:  I agree a capital or debt-raise would provide an extra cushion for losses. The primary gain from such is to enable a “safe level” of possible innovation with technologies like D3Ms or certain RWA structures where the risks are higher than what the community wants to tolerate. But the long-term strategic gain might be there. Again the community of MKR tokenholders need to weight on it. The risks are in the HOW as usual, if the collective of MKR tokenholders think (1) is a good direction for Maker. That is not certain. Maker is an open source protocol, which is one of its core values. Any collective organisation to “design that HOW”, be it by core units, MKR tokenholders, open community, should be transparently agreed upfront in my view. RWF-001 as a core unit is currently not involved in the design of such capital raise. We believe there are benefits to it e.g. innovation, portfolio construction etc. But only if designed/proposed in a non-dilutive and transparent way (the “HOW”).  Last, but not least, I don’t believe the strategy for RWAs is unsuccessful. There is complexity in these securitisations which was build out of the necessity of doing them right. And once done right,  evolving towards automating the processes is the direction of travel in my view. This second piece (i.e. automation) takes time but the learnings gained from doing them through Centrifuge, SocGen, HVB etc are priceless.  Nowhere else in DeFi there is the same experience as Maker is having. Single collateral DAI or Multi collateral DAI weren’t built overnight either. Doing RWAs right and increasingly on-chain are equivalent to such enterprises. SCD started in 2014 and it took more than 4 years to be running with a whole Foundation with dozens of people focused on it. We’re only getting that dedicated focus from committed multi-stakeholder groups right now.

content.content: Simple question: what will the money raised be used for? The answer will determine whether people support it, support Rune or reject both.

I think I have always been okay with a capital raise as long as the protocol remained profitable.  It has been shocking to see how quickly we’ve lost income and at this point, I think those advocating for the raise should consider delaying it until the protocol has recovered.  When you were profitable, a raise wasn’t viewed as suspiciously but now that expenditures are starting to get drawn from the surplus buffer, some people are going to suspect you’re actually raising money to pay yourselves rather than stated intentions for growth.  In fact, as you’ve lost so much DAI from nonstablecoin collateral, you actually need less buffer and have created more room for RWA projects that are spinning up.  I don’t think the argument is there that you are bursting at the seams with loan demand right now while we’re very slowly still figuring out how to integrate RWA and governments across the world are actively trying to slow demand in order to mitigate inflation. Do whatever you need to in order to get back to profitability, integrate some projects with low debt ceilings and get to the point where you’re actually able to quickly increase debt ceilings…then talk about a raise if it’s still necessary. @rune I appreciate the time and thought you have spent on your end game proposal.  I can imagine a world where it works out but I somehow can’t see it happening right now because I feel there isn’t enough people involved with this project to make all the meta dao stuff work.  I think the community needs to grow before trying something radically different like that and we have to find simpler ways to turn things around.

content.content: This question is truly at the core of capital management. Money raised and kept idle won’t be used for anything. Every activity has an estimated (statistically) capital absorption, meaning that has some capital that should be kept aside to protect against ‘unknown unknowns’. The more structured it is, the higher that number is. If the raise will be brought forward, the proponents should provide a detailed estimate of why we need a specific amount of capital aside. The D3Ms greenlit by the community, like TrueFi and Maple, are both very structured and not fully collateralised and although with incredible potential they cannot be scaled without a risk cushion. At the same time I agree with @Traster_Tray - we should first put the rails for growth in place and then implement a raise if needed. And this is what is happening. Discussing and structuring any debt-based solution will require time, so we will have plenty of time to onboard eventually the D3Ms, RWAs, or any solution, at very modest size, and then propose a progressive raise to sustain extending those lines. It is however helpful to have these conversations, given how long it takes to do things well.

content.content: But this is not the full picture right?  You don’t raise just to invest in government bonds because the bond interest is going to be much less than the interest charged on your own bond issuance.  How you invest your assets is more of a way to earn additional income at the cost of liquidity constraint. From how I’ve understood it, the real purpose of raising is so you can increase your DAI debt ceiling on your different collateral types comfortably.  Your buffer only needs to be a small portion of your max debt ceiling so a capital raise used for this purpose enables you to earn much more than the interest you pay on the debt.  You could invest the capital you get on top of that at the expense of liquidity but that’s really just bonus income.

content.content: rune:  100% against as it is centralizing and is being pushed by core units which means it would cause political deterioration and be a de facto vote on making the core units into a centralized management team with zero concrete steps about how to undo that. Also the ideas are decent but not really that great, the main focus seems to be raise money but there’s no clear explanation for what that money should be used for, other than more RWA which i think is very unappealing because our RWA strategy is unfortunately a failure with unacceptable political dysfunction, gargantuan overhead and overwhelming complexity.   I am adding my own views here.  100% against a capital raise for the following reasons:  Every piece of documentation forum posts etc. on this subject - which should read like a prospectus is lacking basic costs, and explicit uses for the capital leading to expected revenues.   No single company would issue a bond, or stock (and this is particularly true of a stock issuance btw) without a exceedingly well thought out prospectus proposal laying out time frames, numbers etc.  But lets look at the basics as I have read them in various places.  Proposed is to raise something like 200M (to give MakerDAO something like 250M in capital) via two methods (or combination).  Selling MKR, borrowing DAI.    No discussion of what is the expected MKR price required to raise X capital.    There was a basic discussion of raising 200M in a bond that would cost up to 10% (1000bps) yr to service (this is up to 20M/yr cost). While I have seen numbers bantered around when I look at Maker RWA vaults they are not going to yield much over 200bps on average.  In fact our average return on all Vaults are basically around 50bps.   I don’t see RWA vaults much over 200-300bps without significant additional risk and long time horizons.  Maker revenues from vaults is now 32M/yr and our expense run is something around 40M not including MKR vesting.    MKR market cap on even a 50M capital raise via MKR sale could easily drop another 200M market cap and require selling 50K MKR.    Interest on even 100M/yr at 5% for a 2-5 yr bond (if we could get that) is going to be 5M/yr.   So when we factor in RWF cost (7M+/yr?!) + the market cap hit and/or bond servicing fee of (5-20M/yr) you have to wonder in what world this makes sense to do?  Add up the numbers cost 5M/yr+7M RWF + perhaps 200M MKR market cap loss to have 250M in the bank which is going to earn us maybe 200bps on 500M (10M).   At a minimum you have to do 2 of these 500M 200bps vaults to be profitable provided these returns hold up and costs don’t go up or returns down.  Or you have to do what 4 200M DC vaults earning 200bps to again just be profitable (this doesn’t include buying back and burning the 50K MKR we sold or the 100M DAI we will need to pay back to bond holders).   We’d have to do what double or triple the above and we can’t even get out of the starting gate on even a 50M vault.  Now I have heard this 250M buffer is going to allow Maker to issue 500-1B RWA vaults.   I have always been an advocate that Maker could always do vaults with DCs that were basically under the current surplus buffer.  The idea here was to grow our existing vaults to that DC level and do ‘many of them’.   Spread the risk to a larger number, but smaller size and generate growing returns from them as you work out the kinks.   Not ideal, but far better than trying to do one single vault of 500M with a SB of 250M because if for any reason the value of that vault becomes inaccessible it basically puts the SB at -250M and DAI undercollateralized in accounting by at least 2-4%.    If everyone is ok with having vaults of 500M-1B with 250M SB what is wrong with having 100-200M vaults with 75M SB?   A sustainable approach is to start reasonably, measurably small and scale as proof of revenues manifests. If the idea is that this capital is to be used to fund L2s, wormholes, expanded CU budgets whatever again I don’t see how these are ever going to fetch us fees over this 200bps level. The only way selling MKR here makes sense is if the DAO believes the MKR price is too high and is going lower in the future.  Then it makes sense to sell MKR to raise capital now and to use it to generate revenues to buy back MKR lower in the future, but be prepared for the PR and market reaction in the MKR price to such an announcement and move. I agree completely with @rune when he suggests:     rune:  No reason to do all those complicated things when we can just put it all in government bonds with simple structures like MIP65 or 6s capital. But even more importantly, this is just not the kind of complexity that should be prioritized at this stage, in my opinion. There are so much more critical things to do, such as fixing governance and budgets.

content.content: Just adding more colour to what discussed here. Although sovereign exposures like US government are risk-weighted at 0 by banks when they calculate their exposures, that weighting refers only to credit risk of the issuer. There are several other risks that might impact such exposure (interest rate / duration risk as indicated by @SebVentures and @flipflopflapdelegate - which with the current IR environment is non-negligible, but also liquidity risk - low, counterparty risk - someone is holding that bond, and business risk in general). Even if low, those risks pile up when dealing with exposures at very hight quantum. It could also be argued that regulators give the benefit of 0 risk weighting to banks when they buy government bonds because they basically want them as buyer of last resort of all the sovereign debt and credit risk is actually not zero at all. The argument, as @MakerMan puts it, is that anything we do that has some type of structuring that goes beyond native $ETH has some type of risk. Counterparty / smart contract risk, liquidity risk - like the $stETH experience is teaching us, etc. We don’t know how much we should keep aside to protect us against such risk, nor whether it will make the equation economical, but I think it’s an analysis that must be done. Obviously those risks expand dramatically when we move off-chain even for perceived low-risk initiatives like MIP65. If we instead discuss about 6s, then the risks are several steps higher. I fully agree with many things said in this thread that we should be careful and rigorous if we want to raise (debt) capital to protect us, because such debt is going to cost us anyhow, and therefore we should do the math correctly to make sure we need it, and that it’s economical and safely managed. What I want to stress, however, is that I don’t feel (IMHO) that the right approach is the other extreme, which is to jump in doing complex structures with little visibility with our eyes closed and hope that everything is going to turn right. This especially today, with market participants ready to attack currencies as soon as the mere suspicion of weakness arises.

content.content: Re interest rates drawing savers back to tradfi, I think fed tightening could be more of an opportunity for DeFi as long as DeFi exploits its competitive advantage. Big banks underserve retail investors and small businesses. As interest rates rise, they will increase their lending rates while keeping savings rates depressed in order to increase net interest margins. They also have huge costs/overhead from red tape, maintaining branches and downtown offices, paying out high executive compensation, legal/accounting costs, regulation etc etc etc. Big banks don’t even want to service retail accounts and small businesses of a certain amount anymore because the administrative costs and risks aren’t worth it when they can just do business with big clients. If you want a loan or line of credit, they either tell you to get a high APR credit card or accept an egregiously high rate. DeFi has a lower cost of capital and can serve some of these underserved markets. Maker can benefit from increased rates because it grows interest rate income and increases competitiveness by undercutting traditional banks. If anything, I would say low interest rates hurt DeFi lending because why figure out DeFi when you can just borrow money against your house at 3%? When people can’t get cheap money from banks anymore, they will shop for competitive rates. I think RWA is where Maker can tap into this competitive advantage and grow higher interest rate lines of business. If we don’t get out into the real world, then the addressable market is just tech enthusiasts swapping tokens with each other.

content.content: I have brought up this point repeatedly because it applies to Maker.   en.wikipedia.org    Impossible trinity The impossible trinity (also known as the impossible trilemma or the Unholy Trinity) is a concept in international economics which states that it is impossible to have all three of the following at the same time:  It is both a hypothesis based on the uncovered interest rate parity condition, and a finding from empirical studies where governments that have tried to simultaneously pursue all three goals have failed. The concept was developed independently by both John Marcus Fleming in 1962 and Rob...      Point here is that with the DAI PEG fixed to 1, and lack of capital controls the only thing one has left is rates, and if someone else is doing the rate management on the thing you are pegging to.  Your rates basically have to match or you face capital outflows. So you are absolutely correct in assessing that Maker reaction to capital outflows is highly tied to rates (both on DSR and on SF).   So SF will have to go up dramatically and so will DSR.  In fact these probably will have to be coupled to match the spread in borrow and savings rates in TradFI. I have also pointed out that should Maker act too slowly, incorrectly, or we just have a hard and fast market event because the PSMs don’t have multiple tier structures (fee spreads) with increasing liquidity (there is one tier with 0 fees on tin/tout) once the PSMs empty it is going to be a PEG free fall that will be left to borrowers to take advantage of (DAI borrowers are in effect DAI short but they need to have cash/capital to buy DAI that is below $1 PEG once the PSMs empty. Treasuries will basically take part of (say USDC in the PSM) and buy USTs with some kind of duration.  Should Maker need this liquidity before maturity in a rate rising environment we will take losses trying to sell to raise cash.   There is an additional point some have mentioned but not really addressed - liquidity issues.   My problem isn’t US treasuries, but the fact we are likely in a rising rate environment which makes it pretty dangerous to try to earn return in RWA using US treasuries, this is especially true if you need this liquidity to be on demand within days vs. months.
